titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the William Christopher Papers, circa 1920s-circa 1973, in the Archives of American Art AAA.chriwill
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Anna Rimel
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record 209576.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-09-01T09:06-0400

did.abstract: The William Christopher papers measure 7.9 linear feet and date from circa 1920s to circa 1973. Materials include biographical materials, correspondence, writings and notes, five diaries, subject/project files, printed materials, photographs, numerous sketches and eleven sketchbooks, and five unidentified motion picture films. The subject/project files include correspondence, printed materials, and two additional diaries about Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and the 1965 civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: William Christopher was a painter, art instructor, and Civil Rights activist living and working in New York, New Hampshire, and Vermont. He was born in Columbus, Georgia on March 4, 1924, and served in the U. S. Navy from 1941 to 1943.

Aided by grants and scholarships, Christopher studied in France at the Sorbonne, Academie Julian, and the Ecoles d’Art Americaines between 1946-1948. While there, he also studied with Ossip Zadkine. He returned to New York and studied with Amedee Ozenfant and Hans Hofmann between 1948 and 1950.

Christopher's paintings was greatly influenced by his time spent in Paris and New York, and his later involvement with the Civil Rights movement, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and the march in Selma in 1965. His first U. S. solo exhibition was in 1952 at the Roko Gallery in New York, and he exhibited widely in New York, Boston, Washington, D.C. at the Nexus Gallery, the Boston Arts Festival, the Corcoran Gallery of Art, Joan Peterson Gallery, Galeria Juana Mordo, and the Whitney Museum of American Art, among others. In 1964, Christopher was invited to present his paintings to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. during the presentation of Dr. King’s papers to Boston University. This is where Christopher met King.
Christopher moved to Hartland, Vermont in 1960, with his partner painter George Tooker. He remained there for the rest of his life. Christopher died in 1973.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Multiple accessions were merged and archivally processed and a finding aid prepared by Anna Rimel in 2015 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution’s Collections Care and Preservation Fund. The Archives of American Art has implemented accelerated processing when possible to increase information about access to more of our collections. For this collection, accelerated processing included arrangement to the series, subseries and folder levels, adhering to the creator’s original arrangement as much as possible. Generally, folder contents were simply verified with the original folder titles, but items within folders were not arranged further. All materials were rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but staples and other fasteners have not all been removed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The William Christopher papers measure 7.9 linear feet and date from circa 1920s to circa 1973. Materials include biographical materials, correspondence, writings and notes, five diaries, subject/project files, printed materials, photographs, numerous sketches and eleven sketchbooks, and five unidentified motion picture films. The subject/project files include correspondence, printed materials, and two additional diaries about Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and the 1965 civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama.

Biographical materials include address books, annotated memorabilia, awards and certificates, curriculum vitae and resume materials, and identification materials. Correspondence is with friends and fellow artists, including actress Osceola Archer and Henry Crapo, galleries, and others. Writings and notes include eleven notebooks, miscellaneous undated notes and papers, annotated drafts and writings by William Christopher, and writings by others. There are five diaries written by William Christopher from the 1940s to the 1960s.

Subject files document miscellaneous projects in which Christopher was involved and/or interested, and include several about Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. containing correspondence, printed material, and two diaries written by Christopher during his attendance of the Civil Rights march from Selma to Montgomery.

Scattered personal business papers concern artwork sold and loaned and personal finances. Printed materials include clippings, exhibition catalogs and materials, magazines and programs, and posters. Photographs are of William Christopher, Henry Crapo, Margaret French, Charles Howard, Bernard Perlin, George Tooker, male models and figures, furniture, landscapes, buildings, and artwork.

Christopher's papers include over one hundred sketches and watercolors, eleven sketchbooks, an artwork by Dimitri Von Mohrenshildt, and one sketch by George Tooker. Also found among the papers are five unidentified film reels made by Christopher for an unfinished project.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives’ Washington, D.C. Research Center. Contact Reference Services for more information.
Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.
Glass plate negatives are housed separately and closed to researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The William Christopher papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: William Christopher papers, circa 1920s-circa 1973. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: William Christopher donated his papers to the Archives of American Art in 1972.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 10 series:

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, circa 1940s-circa 1973 (0.5 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Writings and Notes, circa 1947-1970 (0.4 linear feet; Box 3)
Series 4: Diaries, circa 1940s-circa 1960s (0.2 linear feet; Boxes 3-4)
Series 5: Subject Files, 1943-1972 (0.7 linear feet; Boxes 4, 9)
Series 6: Personal Business Records, circa 1950-circa 1972 (0.3 linear feet; Box 4)
Series 7: Printed Material, circa 1950s-circa 1972 (1.4 linear feet; Boxes 4-5, 9, OV12)
Series 8: Photographs, circa 1920s-circa 1970s (0.7 linear feet; Boxes 6, 8, MGP 4)
Series 9: Artwork and Sketchbooks, circa 1940s-circa 1970s (1.6 linear feet; Boxes 6-8, OV10-11, 13-18)
Series 10: Unidentified Project, Motion Picture Films, 1961 (0.2 linear feet; Box 7)

Civil rights demonstrations--Alabama--Selma

Painters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical material includes five address books, annotated memorabilia, awards and certificates, curriculum vitae and resume materials, and identification materials, including passport, driver’s licenses, operator’s licenses, birth certificate, and membership cards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes invitations from friends, fellow artists, and galleries; medical correspondence with doctors after a series of heart attacks; letters from Harold McNeil Robinson, an African American youth who William Christopher helped finance school; correspondence with actress Osceola Archer; and with Henry Crapo, friend and colleague. Additionally, general correspondence includes friends and galleries, such as Margaret Cross, Gaspare D. Cruchi, and many others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings and notes include eleven notebooks, miscellaneous undated notes and papers, annotated poetry drafts and a story manuscript written by William Christopher. Also included are several writings by others, including an opera manuscript, “Mourning Becomes Electra,” written by Marvin David Levy, and reviews and thesis by Henry H. Crapo.

did.unittitle: Poetry and Story by William Christopher

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five diaries were kept by William Christopher from the 1940s to the 1960s. There are also two additional diaries in the subject files about Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subject files are found for miscellaneous projects and the Civil Rights Movement and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Christopher's files about King include correspondence, printed material, and two diaries Christopher wrote about his attendance of the march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama. Additional files relate to the Vestris Prize for Choreography, for which Henry Crapo was the sponsor and trustee of the Wasemaquia Charitable Trust Company, and Christopher, George Tooker, and choreographer Stuart Hodes, were judges. Other files relate to a Guggenheim proposed project, Veteran's Adminstration, Galeria Juana Mordo, Vincent Smith, and sculpture by Judith Brown. Files may contain correspondence, printed matter, drafts of writings and ideas, photographs, and clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized materials housed in Box 8.

did.unittitle: Oversized Materials, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scattered personal business records include one account ledger, loan agreements, financial correspondence, invoices and bills paid, receipts, price lists, an apartment lease, and a cursory draft of William Christopher’s will.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes clippings, exhibition catalogs and materials, magazines and programs, and posters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 8.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by subject. Glass plate negatives are housed separately and closed to researchers, but listed where they fall intellectually within the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs include original photographs, negatives, slides, and one glass plate negative. Images depict William Christopher and George Tooker; friends, including Charles Howard, Henry Crapo, Margaret French, and Bernard Perlin; male models and figures; furniture; landscapes and buildings; artwork; and several x-rays of William Christopher’s head and chest.

did.unittitle: Photographs of William Christopher and Geoge Tooker
Photographs of William Christopher, Friends, and Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized materials housed in Box 9. 1 glass plate negative housed in MGP 4.

did.unittitle: Photographs and Negatives of Male Models
Oversized Photographs of William Christopher, Friends, and Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork and sketchbooks consists of over one hundred sketches and watercolors and eleven sketchbooks. Works by others include a piece by Dimitri Von Mohrenshildt and a sketch by George Tooker. eleven sketchbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 9, OV10-11, 13-18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 9, OV10-11, 13-18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Motion picture films consists of five film reels made by William Christopher for an unidentified and unfinished project.
